posts.name: Mehir
posts.cooked:
We want to try to balance during auto and want to implement a pid controller to do so. But we’re running into issues. Here’s what we did:

We are using our navx gyro to get the pitch of the robot and have a p controller (currently) to balance. To tune the p value the wpilib documentation says we have to keep increasing p until the current angle oscillates around the set point (0 degrees). This is where we’re kind of confused. It seems that once the robot starts sliding off the other side of the ramp it does not have a chance to apply voltage to come back up and just slides off completely meaning we can’t really see the oscillation occurring on the graph. We tried reducing the p value but at some point our robot was able to balance correctly without having a chance to start sliding off the other swith minimal oscillation. My concern with this happening is that our charge station is less sensitive than the real thing which might mean it might not work when we retune at the competition. Am I misunderstanding how PID works?

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: Your robot should drive backwards when tipped the other way. What is your p controller returning when the station tips?

posts.name: Mehir
posts.cooked: We tested if our pid loop was working as intended by starting the robot on the other side of the charge station and it did up the ramp. Now that I think about it I think adding a derivative term will help fix our issue  because just a p controller is too late to react to the charge station falling down.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: P only does work if you drive slowly. To get the cone placed, drive across the Charge Station to get mobility then back onto the Charge Station we drove somewhat fast to almost the balance point then go slowly. We took the allotted 18 seconds.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: d can help dampen oscillation but no, it will not fix the problem completely. The issue is feed back is delayed because the station takes time to fall. You need to drive slowly to give it time to react.

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked:
A problem we were having was that the second the charge station started to tilt backwards, the pitch would change dramatically and our robot would over correct and flip. Experimenting with derivative didn’t seem to do much either  (May be due to the robot not having a low enough center of gravity).

Either way, I figured here would be a good place to ask how others have approached balancing. Whether that be PID or other methods. Bounce some ideas around and hopefully answer OP’s question in the process.

posts.name: Newton Crosby Jr
posts.cooked:
If you haven’t been able to get a normal PID controller to work, I recommend reading into a BangBang controller.

As WPIlib’s page about it will warn you, it’s a very aggressive control method because the controller itself only returns 0 or 1 when you use calculate() . In short a bang bang controller will give you 1 as an output until you reach the desired setpoint, then returns 0 once you’re there. Now, I’ll restate that Bang Bang control is a very aggressive control, and you should only use it on a drive train if you are significantly clamping the value (our balance command uses 0.2 and -0.185) so that you aren’t full-sending on or off the ramp during auto, and most likely  getting disabled.

You’d give it a pitch value as a measurement, and the setpoint would be the pitch (in degrees) that you’d want to stop moving forward at.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!

posts.custom_user_title: Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: The delay from being where you need to be to when it reads level is the problem.   For this reason bang bang is the worst possible option.  An option we are exploring but didn’t have time to fully tune due to need for robot repair over practice field time is is the absolute value of the previous pitch is more than the absolute value of the current pitch then sit still because the pitch is getting better.

posts.name: Vincent Zhao
posts.cooked:
Our team uses a PID controller as well, the way we implement is having the drivetrain run at a highish velocity for a short time to get onto the charge station and then running a PID loop, however scaling our velocity value down a lot so that it better reacts to the charge station changing your pitch.

Also a simple way to verify your PID loop is working accurately is to tilt your robot upwards and the wheels should drive towards the upward tilt and make sure to do this on both sides just to verify.

posts.name: Newton Crosby Jr
posts.cooked: Our robot uses a bang bang for auto, and so far the only time we’ve missed an engaged dock is when our bumpers got caught on the ramp and we simply couldn’t climb. The ‘delay’ you’re talking about hasn’t been a problem at all for us.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!

posts.custom_user_title: Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Bang bang is basically a P controller with a very large gain… generally the opposite of what you want in a system with delays like the ramp

posts.name: Christian
posts.cooked: Our team uses a bang bang controller that stops when the ramp first starts to tip. We noticed that when the ramp is balanced enough to start tipping back to level, it just keeps going, so you want to stop your robot so it doesn’t overtip. This effectively negates the delay.

With PID (actually just P) compensation to drive “uphill” our robot tended to keep going back and forth since the charge station would not settle to “level” but flip from one extreme to the other. Simply going way slow helps, but then you are way slow. Next we tried reducing the P gain each time the charge station flips, so you go slower and slower. It would still take several back/forth moves to settle. Finally, what seemed to work best was driving “up” until it either levels or flips. If it’s level, perfect. Otherwise, just drive ca. 15cm “back” and that would typically be it.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: This is exactly what we did and it worked great

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: P + D did the trick for us but we were frustrated for a bit until we realized we had a rate of change ramp intended for teleop mode that was still in the loop causing another delay. We got rid of that ramp for autonomous balancing and after that we were able to tune it fairly well.
